text:
Ashley Park Was â€œSo Nervousâ€ About Emily In Paris Fan Reaction To Mindyâ€™s Hookup With [Spoiler]

Minor spoilers for Emily in Paris Season 5 ahead. Emily In Paris is back for another season of champagne-fueled chaos, couture-level escapism, and questionable romantic decisions, all wrapped in a brightly-filtered fantasy where the stakes are low, the outfits are loud, and the drama is deliciously unserious. If youâ€™ve been watching the show for four seasons, you know that itâ€™s usually Emily (Lily Collins) in the midst of an ill-advised cobblestone alleyway makeout and while her bestie Mindy (Ashley Park) is no stranger to a love triangle, sheâ€™s usually the one dishing out advice for Emily on her messy entanglements instead of finding herself wrapped up in them herself. Not this season.Â 

Enter the scandal no one saw coming but everyone will have an opinion on: Alfie and Mindy. Yes, that Alfie (Lucien Laviscount) â€” Emilyâ€™s charming, handsome, British, jilted, (did I mention handsome?) ex â€” and Mindy, the glitter-soaked pop princess whose devotion to Emily is as strong as her impressive vocals. At the end of last season, Mindy was single, fresh off a breakup with Nico (Parkâ€™s real-life ex, Paul Forman), and moving on from BenoÃ®t (Kevin Dias) and her band after they got disqualified from Eurovision. This season, she flees to Rome to join Emily and outrun her problems, and runs straight into Alfie. Of course, drama is destined to ensue after you sleep with your best friendâ€™s ex, and it would be easy to write this off as a Season 5 gimmick the writers threw in because they were searching for storylines, but the Alfie and Mindy hookup feels fresh.Â 

First of all, the chemistry between Park and Laviscount is surprisingly steamy considering theyâ€™ve interacted onscreen for seasons without even a hint of a spark. But this season, itâ€™s electric. What begins as a â€œwhen in Romeâ€ moment (sparked by boredom, champagne, and more champagne) detonates into the most deliciously messy hookup the series has ever served, threatening the fragile ecosystem of Emilyâ€™s inner circle. Like moving the series to Rome (temporarily), the new relationship has injected a much-needed jolt into a series that had been floundering under pretty clothes, quips about Parisian cliches, and not much else. This unsuspecting situationship is exactly what the show needed.Â 

I tell Park and Collins how much Iâ€™m feeling Alfie and Mindy together over Zoom during the showâ€™s press junket. The real-life best friends are in Paris, naturally. â€œIâ€™ve been so nervous how people are going to [react]!â€ Park says, relieved. Collins chimes in: â€œThatâ€™s great. We love that!â€

When I ask for more of their thoughts on Alfie and Mindy and the ethics of hooking up with your best friendâ€™s ex, Park has a lot to say. â€œThe main thing in terms of girl code and your best friendâ€™s ex [is] first of all, Emily broke up with Alfie, there were a couple relationships [in between], thereâ€™s time thatâ€™s passed,â€ Park says. â€œI think that the hurt that is caused is because [Emily and Mindy] have always been each otherâ€™s safe place, and theyâ€™ve always been nothing but honest with each other. And for Mindy to be leading her life out of fear and assuming and projecting that Emilyâ€™s gonna feel a certain way towards it, and not giving her the opportunity to be happy for her, thatâ€™s not friendship. Itâ€™s the first time we see that tested.â€Â Â 

As a viewer, the Alfie-Mindy situation feels both deeply wrong and impossibly right, raising thorny questions about loyalty, desire, and whether a friendship can withstand this kind of betrayal. But Park sees it differently: â€œItâ€™s not necessarily about, oh, you slept with my ex, itâ€™s how could you not trust that I would be so happy for you? When we first heard about this might be a plot line, I really thought it was a joke, and I called [Lily], and I was like, â€˜Wait, whatâ€™s going onâ€™? But itâ€™s because I didnâ€™t see how the story was going to blossom and flourish and in the end really deepen their sisterhood. And I think thatâ€™s something we really enjoyed doing.â€

Collins agrees, but when it comes to Emilyâ€™s love life, her advice for her character is to stay away from the drama. â€œItâ€™s okay to not have somebody that youâ€™re interested in. Like, you donâ€™t have to have somebody to be somebody,â€ Collins says. Itâ€™s a lesson that Emily is learning in real time this season as she starts a new romance with Marcello (Eugenio Franceschini) in Rome. But will Emily dive back into a serious relationship so soon after ending things with Gabriel (Lucas Bravo)? Collins teases that with a new gig and new city comes a new outlook for Emily: â€œThis year, we get to see her just being okay and saying this isnâ€™t for me, and not being afraid of what the other person is going to say,â€ she says. â€œItâ€™s the first time sheâ€™s been really honest with the person sheâ€™s talking to in her romantic life. I love that because I think thereâ€™s societal pressure for people who are single to want to be in a relationship. But thereâ€™s such a beautiful thing about Emily being single and being like, hereâ€™s my focus, and here I am. I think thatâ€™s really cool.â€Â 

Itâ€™s also cool that Emily (via Collins) has a new, sharp bob this season. Usually, when a female character comes back from a hiatus with shorter hair, itâ€™s because sheâ€™s shedding layers after a breakup (Felicity from Felicity) or as a cruel punishment (Aria in Pretty Little Liars), mostly because of a man. Emilyâ€™s bob is barely even explained this season, and Collins loves that decision. â€œShe didnâ€™t even need to explain it,â€ she says. â€œIt was just like a life choice. Sheâ€™s like, Okay, Iâ€™m gonna change my hair. So what?â€Â 

Youâ€™ll have to turn into Emily In Paris Season 5 to see if Emily is just as chill about Alfie and Mindy. This season dares us to decide if their hookup is a betrayal or the most honest thing either of them have done all series. Iâ€™m going with the latter. Both Alfie and Mindy have been done dirty in the romance department over the seasons and itâ€™s time they get their happily ever after. I just hope itâ€™s together. I also love seeing an interracial couple on mainstream TV that doesnâ€™t involve a white person because that representation is still so rare. Letâ€™s just forget that Alfie and Mindyâ€™s pairing comes with a side of betrayal. Hey, we watch Emily in Paris for the escape, the eye-candy, the kissing, and the outfits. Itâ€™s a fantasy that thrives on us turning off our brains for a bit and sinking into the comforting belief that even the most unlikely connections can feel inevitableâ€¦ especially in Paris! Or Rome? Or whatever European adventure the show wants to take us on next.Â Emily In Paris Season 5 is streaming now on Netflix.

title: You Didnâ€™t Have To Be In Bondi For It To Hurt
text:
You Didnâ€™t Have To Be In Bondi For It To Hurt

Content warning: This article discusses violence in a way that may be distressing to some readers. It was original published on Refinery29â€™s Australia edition.

On the first night of Hanukkah, beneath the quintessential glow of a Sydney summer evening, globally beloved and iconic Bondi Beach turned from a scene of joy to one of terror. Families and friends had gathered for a festive beachfront celebration, lighting the menorah and singing songs, when gunfire shattered the laughter. Two gunmen, a father and son armed with rifles, opened fire on the crowd, killing at least 15 people (including a child) and injuring dozens more. One attacker was shot dead by police, and the other was wounded and arrested amid the chaos. Australian authorities swiftly declared it a terrorist attack motivated by antisemitic hatred, an assault on the Jewish community that Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has said â€œstruck at the heart of the nationâ€. What should have been a night of light and hope became Australiaâ€™s worst mass shooting in nearly 30 years.

The next morning, Bondiâ€™s sands lay empty and silent, an unheard-of phenomenon for one of the most popular shorelines in the country, save for investigators pacing the cordoned-off area. Since then, the stories and the heroism of bystanders who tried to stop the shooters have dominated headlines. Yet the impact of this attack cannot be measured only in lives lost or injuries. Its shockwaves have rippled far beyond those who stood on the sand that night; the tragedy has seared itself into the psyche of people around the world, including many who were nowhere near Bondi Beach when it happened.

Beyond The Shore

Not even in the hours after the attack, but during, phones pinged with news alerts across Australia and overseas. Many who read the headlines or watched grainy and graphic videos felt a chill of grief and fear. It didnâ€™t matter that they were seeing it through a screen; their hearts broke, and their fear was felt in real time. In Sydney, thousands gathered at vigils the next day, mourners at Bondi laid flowers and sang prayers under the open sky. Similar tributes appeared in other cities, in Melbourne, in London outside the Australian High Commission, and beyond â€” a sign that the world was mourning with Bondi.

â€œCollective trauma can impact how we view the world and how we see ourselves in it â€” the social norms and security we were used to are challenged, making us feel unsafe and unsure, and grieving the world we understood,â€ explains Mental Health Therapist Tammi Miller.

According to Principal Psychologist at Umeed Psychology, Anushka Phal, this reaction is a form of collective trauma or vicarious trauma. â€œHumans donâ€™t exist in isolation; weâ€™re part of communities,â€ Phal describes this as identity-based trauma: â€œFor people with histories of trauma, chronic stress, racism, gender-based violence, or migration stress, the nervous system is already primed to ask: Am I safe? Am I next? The body doesnâ€™t treat it as â€˜newsâ€™ â€” it treats it as confirmation.â€ She adds: â€œEven secondhand exposure can activate the threat system â€” particularly in a 24/7 media environment. The nervous system doesnâ€™t respond to logic; it responds to danger cues, which can show up as hypervigilance, irritability, flatness, grief, and even physical symptoms.â€

Decades of research on vicarious traumatization show that people can develop stress symptoms from simply hearing about or seeing footage of violent events. Our brains, in a sense, replay the horror as if we were there. One study even found that individuals with no prior trauma who watched distressing news reports showed symptoms of secondary traumatic stress, such as anxiety, nightmares, and feelings of helplessness. In the case of the Bondi attack, it brutally resonated far and wide â€“ from the Jewish community in Sydney to anyone who has ever set foot on Bondi.

As Rachel Tomlinson, a Sydney-based therapist (and one of many professionals volunteering at community support sessions this week), points out: â€œTrauma is processed through the nervous system first, not the thinking brain. Thatâ€™s why people feel sick, shaky, or disconnected â€” the body is responding to a perceived threat even before we can name the emotion.â€

She continues, â€œEven indirect exposure â€” like media â€” can activate this system. Freeze or dissociation responses are just as real as panic. You might feel emotionally flat, stuck, or spaced out. Itâ€™s a survival response, not weakness.â€

Coping With The Invisible Wounds

1. Mental health experts emphasize that your feelings are valid. Even if you were not physically present. Thereâ€™s no need to say, â€œI wasnâ€™t there, so I shouldnâ€™t be this upset.â€ Grief, anger, fear, outrage, and numbness, all of these are natural responses. â€œGive yourself permission to feel whatever comes,â€ advises Anushka Phal. â€œDonâ€™t bottle it up just because you werenâ€™t at the scene. Youâ€™re human, and at our core, humans care about each other.â€ Acknowledging the pain is a first step to healing. That might mean talking to friends or family about how the news affected you, or writing down your thoughts in a journal. Some find comfort in attending vigils or religious services to honor the victims, as coming together in solidarity can ease the sense of powerlessness. Others might light a candle at home or say a prayer as a personal act of remembrance.

2. Limiting media exposure is another important coping strategy. While itâ€™s natural to seek information after a traumatic event, endlessly scrolling through graphic images or videos can retraumatize you. â€œBeing unable to control when or what imagery you see following an event like the Bondi attack can make it difficult to self-regulate,â€ says Miller. â€œRepeated exposure can trigger a stress response â€” difficulty sleeping, irritability, trouble concentrating. Itâ€™s important to remember that you are safe in these moments, to look around you and name three things you can see, touch, feel, practise deep breathing and centering, and definitely to seek support from a confidant or trained mental health professional.â€

3. Connecting with others is crucial in these times. The Bondi Beach community has exemplified this â€“ within 24 hours, thousands of people gathered to comfort one another, sing together, and remind themselves that they are not alone. Whether you attend a local vigil or simply call a friend to talk, sharing your feelings can lighten the emotional load. Sometimes just hearing someone say â€œI feel it tooâ€ can be profoundly validating. If your distress persists or feels overwhelming, consider reaching out to a mental health professional. Therapists are aware that indirect trauma is real and can help you work through it. There is no shame in seeking help; it doesnâ€™t matter that â€œit didnâ€™t happen to me,â€ what matters is that it affected you, and getting support is a sign of strength, not weakness.

4. Finally, it can be healing to channel your emotions into positive action. Donate to a victims fund. Support crisis lines like Lifeline, which are seeing a huge surge in calls and will continue to through the holidays. Volunteer your time if you have capacity â€” or if you donâ€™t, drop off a meal, check in on a friend, walk someone home. Acts of care donâ€™t need to be big to matter. They just need to happen.

Finding Light After The Darkness

In the days since the attack, the golden sands of Bondi have been blanketed with flowers, candles, and handwritten messages. Strangers hug each other on the promenade, united in grief. The air carries the mingled scents of saltwater and candle wax as the sun sets each evening over a beach that is healing from trauma seen and unseen. The emotional wounds from that night will take time to mend, and some scars may never fully fade. But amid the sorrow, there is a steadfast resolve that the forces of hatred will not break the spirit of the community.

For anyone struggling with heavy emotions after this tragedy, know that you are entitled to those feelings, they speak to your empathy, and that with time and support, the fear and anguish can evolve into strength and meaning.

Further Support

â€“ Walk-in help available daily at Intercontinental Coogee (8am â€“ 8pm).
â€“ Safe Haven at Sydney Childrenâ€™s Hospital for young people (10am â€“ 7:30pm).
â€“ NSW clinicians are also on the ground at Bondi and Coogee; look for bright vests.

Helplines:
â€“ Lifeline: 13 11 14
â€“ NSW Mental Health Line: 1800 011 511
â€“ Beyond Blue: 1300 22 4636
â€“ Kids Helpline: 1800 55 1800

Find A Psychologist:
â€“ Tala Thrive: A directory that helps you find culturally responsive and trauma-informed therapists across Australia.
â€“ Australian Psychological Society: The largest peak professional body for psychologists and psychology in Australia.Â 
â€“ Check with your GP: Many psychologists can only be accessed with a mental health care plan referral, which allows you to claim Medicare rebates.
â€“ University Clinics: If cost is a barrier, psychology clinics at universities often offer low-fee sessions with provisional psychologists under supervision.

Self-declared â€œlousy shopperâ€ Parker explains: â€œI just think itâ€™s really helpful and really user-friendly, and Iâ€™m hoping it kind of cuts out some of the chaos and hysteria around shopping,â€ adding: â€œI think this idea of Google Shopping with the ability to actually see it on your person takes some of that intimidation away, but also you feel more assured that youâ€™re purchasing something that will likely really suit the occasion and your person.â€

title: Andra Day Says Bradley Cooper â€œBacked Up His Supportâ€ By Casting Her As His Wife In Is This Thing On?
text:
Andra Day Says Bradley Cooper â€œBacked Up His Supportâ€ By Casting Her As His Wife In Is This Thing On?

Is This Thing On? may not seem like a movie where youâ€™d find Grammy-award winner and Oscar nominee Andra Day. Itâ€™s about a white man doing stand-up comedy after all. But the Bradley Cooper-directed divorce dramedy starring Will Arnett and Laura Dern wouldnâ€™t be complete without Day, who brings some brutal honesty and a delightful groundedness to the film. She plays Christine, the best friend to Dernâ€™s Tess, and the wife of Cooperâ€™s Balls (yes, thatâ€™s really his characterâ€™s name). Tess is going through a divorce with Arnettâ€™s Alex, who turns to stand-up comedy to cope with their breakup. Day is so good as Christine in every scene, it feels like youâ€™re eavesdropping on old friends who canâ€™t help but tell each other the truth â€” no matter how uncomfortable.Â 

Cooper handpicked Day for the role and was sure sheâ€™d say no. â€œI was just crossing my fingers with Andra,â€ Cooper says in the filmâ€™s production notes. â€œI just knew she would say no, but I had to offer it to her. When I saw The United States vs. Billie Holliday, I was floored. I was like, â€˜Look, I apologize that the real estate is going to be small here, but here is the terrain. Would you please come do this with me?â€™ It was a huge coup to get her.â€ And with the small real estate Day is given, she builds a brick house. Itâ€™s a no-bullshit performance that leaps off the screen, leaving the audience wanting more of Christine. And the dynamic between her and Tess â€œmakes for a delicious, spiky friendship,â€ Dern says.Â 

Here, Day talks about Cooperâ€™s support, building rapport with Dern, singing with Sean Hayes, and why sheâ€™d never get back together with an ex.

Refinery29 Unbothered: I loved the film and was surprised by how much I was moved by it! I know that Bradley Cooper said he had to convince you, or that when he asked you to do this, he didnâ€™t think you would say yes.Â 

Andra Day: Is this what heâ€™s telling people? [laughs] He did not have to convince me of anything! He just popped on the screen and he was Bradley Cooper and I was like, â€œgreat idea, letâ€™s work together!â€ Heâ€™s so funny. I genuinely was very excited to be a part of [this movie]. Iâ€™m a huge fan of his work as an actor. Iâ€™m a huge fan of his work as a director. I just think heâ€™s just shown heâ€™s just such a brilliant director. Heâ€™s just a great filmmaker. So I was excited. I was like, â€œIâ€™m actually looking forward to being in your hands and seeing what you put together with this cast.â€ Iâ€™m so glad you love the movie. And maybe Iâ€™m biased, but I love the movie too.

Tell me more about why you chose to take on this role.

AD: I was really moved by [Bradley Cooperâ€™s] support. I also knew that he was really supportive of two other movies I had done. So for him to back up that support with the offer to play this character, I thought was really, really special. And then he starts describing the movie to me. Itâ€™s Will Arnettâ€™s baby, and theyâ€™ve been friends for such a long time. So I love that it was he [cast] himself as [the character] Balls, because who else better to play Willâ€™s best friend than his actual best friend? I love the dynamic of the friend group. I love the themes of truth, of rediscovery, of transformation, and communication, and just growth. I think itâ€™s so funny. We always talk about growth, but we never allow each other to change. So I love that the movie dealt with all of those themes. And then Bradley mentioned the names Will Arnett, Laura Dern and Sean Hayes. And I was like, this is all just getting too crazy. They are all just so great. It was a dream cast to work with and it was exactly what I thought it would be. And better.

I love what you just said: â€œwe always talk about growth, but we donâ€™t allow each other to change.â€ That was a bar!Â 

AD: You know, maybe I was a little rapper in my past life [laughs]. Nah, Iâ€™m just kidding but I think itâ€™s true!Â 

I want to talk about that cast that you mentioned, because there are some heavy hitters. You play Laura Dernâ€™s best friend, Christine. Talk about building that rapport with Laura Dern, because it does feel like youâ€™re just dropped into this years-long friendship. How did you build that rapport?

AD: Itâ€™s amazing to feel like you were just dropped in this relationship. I think thatâ€™s a testament to the great writing, the great direction and how it was shot, but also the truth.Â  Bradley absolutely requires truth. Thatâ€™s the thing weâ€™re looking for. But working with Laura, first of all, Iâ€™m just such a huge fan of her work. Laura plays such an array of characters, and so, of course, you walk into her space and youâ€™re intimidated at first. You got to make sure you show up and support and youâ€™re present but beyond that, being able to work with Laura and discovering, oh, wow, she is amazing. Sheâ€™s great at what she does, and a huge part of that is how generous she is on set, how generous she is with not just the director and her co stars, but everyone on set, every actor, personnel on set and and how honest and open she is about herself as a human, and how much of that she brings to the character.Â 

Christine is such a protective friend.

AD: I love that you see that! [laughs]Â 

Sheâ€™s like, donâ€™t mess with my girl! How protective of a friend are you? Could you relate to that in Christine?

AD: No, I have ADHD, so I canâ€™t focus on shit. Most of the time I donâ€™t even remember. [laughs] Iâ€™m just kidding! No,I think I am a protective friend. [gestures off camera]. Look, I have a friend in the room thatâ€™s nodding her head â€œyesâ€ and laughing right now.

I think I am definitely a protective friend, for sure. What I like about Christine, though, is that she is a protective friend, but she will also protect you from yourself. I think that what I love about her character is her brutal honesty. I think what makes it so not just digestible, but actually endearing, is the fact that she is equally as brutally honest with herself. Thatâ€™s really the only way to be honest with someone, thatâ€™s the only way they can actually trust your advice or your critique, if that they know that you hold yourself to that same standard. I think weâ€™re similar in that way. I can be very protective, and not just physically, but also emotionally when it comes to friends and people that I love.

Stand-up comedy is the beating heart throughout this film. Is stand-up something youâ€™ve ever thought about doing? Did this movie change your opinion of it at all?Â 

AD: Stand-up comedy is never something I ever thought about doing, and still have never thought about doing because it looks terrifying to me. You know whatâ€™s funny, I was sayingÂ  about the movie that it makes me laugh when we describe John Bishop [who inspired] Will Arnettâ€™s character, Alex Novak, and theyâ€™re like, â€œYeah, he just kind of did this stand-up because he didnâ€™t want to pay the cover.â€ And Iâ€™m like, â€œguys, thatâ€™s not normal.â€ [laughs]. Like, if it were me, and someone was like, you can either pay the cover or you can go do stand up. Iâ€™m either coming out of my pocket 15 bucks or Iâ€™m going to the restaurant down the street. Iâ€™m not going to do a set of stand-up for $15!Â  Itâ€™s too terrifying.Â 

I think it takes something inherently in you to do that. But what I learned was about the community of stand-up. I think itâ€™s an incredible community. Bradley [Cooper] has always loved stand-up. And I think we all have, right? The Richard Pryors, Eddie Murphys. But the connectedness and the camaraderie were amazing to me. It used to be a lot more competitive. Now, when you dip into the culture, you realize that theyâ€™re doing, like, 3 to 6, clubs a night, which is insane. The grind is such that Iâ€™ve always admired stand-up comics, I loved to see how connected they are. And I think that Bradley [Cooper] and Will [Arnett] did an incredible job of showing this community, how they support each other, how they joke, and how honest they are as people.

Thereâ€™s this incredible scene where you and Sean Hayes sing â€œAmazing Grace.â€ How did that come to be?

AD: First, I love singing with Sean. I love Seanâ€™s voice. Twas an amazing scene to shoot. It was amazing because it wasnâ€™t written in the script. The night before, I got a call from Bradley that was like, â€œWhat do you think about singing â€˜Amazing Graceâ€™?â€ I was like, â€œSure!â€ That was one of the later scenes we shot and I was, I was used to us being on set and being able to pivot. Who knows if it would be amazing or if itâ€™d be really cringe and weird? I didnâ€™t know. But it worked.

That scene, for me, and a lot of the Oyster Bay scenes, helped me to feel much more a part of this group. It just felt like we just were enjoying each otherâ€™s presence while we were on set filming that scene. And then I think it translated for the audience â€” them singing Amazing Grace added like, 10 or 15 years to their friendship.Â 

Weâ€™re going to end on a little game. Iâ€™m going to give you scenarios â€” based on the movie â€” and the answers are either â€œBothered or Unbothered.â€ Your partner decides to become a stand up comedian later in life, bothered or unbothered?Â 

AD: Unbothered! Iâ€™m an artist in that way. Iâ€™m just kind of like, â€œyouâ€™re fine. Try it if you love it!â€

You donâ€™t like your best friendâ€™s husband: bothered or unbothered?

AD: Super bothered! Super duper bothered!Â 

Telling your best friendâ€™s man you used to have a crush on him.

AD: Oohh. This is where I differ from my character. Iâ€™m a little more bothered about that.

Getting back together with an ex.

AD: Bothered, bothered, bothered! You an ex for a reason.

Your friend doesnâ€™t tell you she got back together with her ex. Bothered or unbothered?

AD: Bothered. Not because you got back with your ex â€” unless heâ€™s a toxic ex â€” Iâ€™m like, sis, what are we doing? Bothered, because if heâ€™s a decent person, then what am I doing that made you feel uncomfortable to talk to me about that? If weâ€™re best friends and Iâ€™m a confidant, then Iâ€™m bothered a little bit with myself and the situation.

When people announce their breakup on social media or publicly.

AD: I donâ€™t care. Unbothered. Iâ€™m like, do you! Who cares?

Finally, using your personal life as fodder for art or comedy, bothered or unbothered?

AD: Unbothered, thatâ€™s actually art and comedy. Iâ€™m bothered when you donâ€™t use it at all. You know what Iâ€™m saying? Thatâ€™s when Iâ€™m bothered.
